commit_message:
Don't persist RequestSpec.retry

During a resize, the RequestSpec.flavor is updated
to the new flavor. If the resize failed on one host
and was rescheduled, the RequestSpec.retry is updated
for that failed host and mistakenly persisted, which
can affect later move operations, like if an admin
targets one of those previously failed hosts for a
live migration or evacuate operation.

This change fixes the problem by not ever persisting
the RequestSpec.retry field to the database, since
retries are per-request/operation and not something
that needs to be persisted.

Alternative to this, we could reset the retry field
in the RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations method
but that would be slightly overloading the meaning
of that method, and the approach taken in this patch
is arguably cleaner since retries shouldn't ever be
persisted. It should be noted, however, that one
advantage to resetting the 'retry' field in the
RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations method would
be to avoid this issue for any existing DB entries
that have this problem.

The related functional regression test is updated
to show the bug is now fixed.

NOTE(mriedem): This backport also includes change
I61f745667f4c003d7e3ca6f2f9a99194930ac892 squashed
into it in order to not re-introduce that bug.

Change-Id: Iadbf8ec935565a6d4ccf6f36ef630ab6bf1bea5d
Closes-Bug: #1718512
(cherry picked from commit 6647f11dc1aba89f9b0e2703f236a43f31d88079)

[{'created': '2018-04-10 20:39:29.000000000', 'message': 'Add regression test for persisted RequestSpec.retry from failed resize

Commit 74ab427d4796d8a386f84a15cc49188c2a60f8f1 in Newton added
code to persist changes to the RequestSpec during a resize since
the flavor changes.

That change inadvertantly also persisted any failed hosts during
the resize that are stored in the RequestSpec.retry field during
a reschedule.

The problem is that later those persisted failed hosts are rejected
by the RetryFilter, which can be confusing if an admin is trying
to live migrate or evacate the instance to one of those specific
hosts.

This adds a functional regression test to show the failure, which
will be fixed in a separate change that then modifies the assertions.

Change-Id: Ib8a23db838b0bbf2cfb8123cf6aaa39d00ff0640
Related-Bug: #1718512
(cherry picked from commit 89448bea577b30c40ce39185d14fe14f9c61a0c2)
'}]
commit_message:
Add regression test for persisted RequestSpec.retry from failed resize

Commit 74ab427d4796d8a386f84a15cc49188c2a60f8f1 in Newton added
code to persist changes to the RequestSpec during a resize since
the flavor changes.

That change inadvertantly also persisted any failed hosts during
the resize that are stored in the RequestSpec.retry field during
a reschedule.

The problem is that later those persisted failed hosts are rejected
by the RetryFilter, which can be confusing if an admin is trying
to live migrate or evacate the instance to one of those specific
hosts.

This adds a functional regression test to show the failure, which
will be fixed in a separate change that then modifies the assertions.

Change-Id: Ib8a23db838b0bbf2cfb8123cf6aaa39d00ff0640
Related-Bug: #1718512
(cherry picked from commit 89448bea577b30c40ce39185d14fe14f9c61a0c2)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-17 12:06:03.000000000', 'message': "Consume RoleData config from config download files

In https://review.openstack.org/#/c/525260/, we moved the creation of
various RoleData driven config files to deploy-steps-tasks.yaml, and to
consume the values from various role_data_* variables that were written in
the inventory (see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/528354/).

However, we were already downloading and saving the RoleData to separate
files via config download. We should consume from those files instead of
the inventory. That has the advantage that one can quickly modify and
iterate on the local files, and have those changes applied. That is
harder to do when these values are in the inventory, and not possible to
do when using dynamic inventory.

Since the tasks will fail trying to read from the files when not using
config-download, conditional local_action tasks that use the stat module
first verify the existence of the files before attempting to read their
contents. If they don't exist, the values fall back to whatever has been
defined by the ansible variable.

Change-Id: Idfdce6f0a778b0a7f2fed17ff56d1a3e451868ab
Closes-Bug: #1749784
(cherry picked from commit c334ad38d51482512dab1887013a052a76e24f81)
"}]
commit_message:
Consume RoleData config from config download files

In https://review.openstack.org/#/c/525260/, we moved the creation of
various RoleData driven config files to deploy-steps-tasks.yaml, and to
consume the values from various role_data_* variables that were written in
the inventory (see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/528354/).

However, we were already downloading and saving the RoleData to separate
files via config download. We should consume from those files instead of
the inventory. That has the advantage that one can quickly modify and
iterate on the local files, and have those changes applied. That is
harder to do when these values are in the inventory, and not possible to
do when using dynamic inventory.

Since the tasks will fail trying to read from the files when not using
config-download, conditional local_action tasks that use the stat module
first verify the existence of the files before attempting to read their
contents. If they don't exist, the values fall back to whatever has been
defined by the ansible variable.

Change-Id: Idfdce6f0a778b0a7f2fed17ff56d1a3e451868ab
Closes-Bug: #1749784
(cherry picked from commit c334ad38d51482512dab1887013a052a76e24f81)

commit_message:
Added getting immediate rated tenant list feature

For now, cloudkitty returns the rated tenant list based on history
rated data from the database (of course the rated tenant list is also
history, a tenant will still appear in the rated tenant list even the
rating role of the tenant was removed recently). Sometimes, end user
want to know which tenants are in the state of rating just for the
present moment, this patch add an option "only_now" to the
report-tenant-list API. If the option is true, this API will get the
rated tenant list from the keystone rather than from the database.

Change-Id: Ia963d22fdd2722b7dd5528cb5b782954f892e7ee

commit_message:
Add validation task in docker services [Octavia]

Docker services are missing the pre-upgrade validation task
in the upgrade_tasks section which verifies if the service
is running before going on with the upgrade.

Change-Id: I72da8e027b6da654bda328d4540ec1e6ed9767ff
Partial-Bug: #1704389
(cherry picked from commit f5ffd40ada03b608cf6e91961013b72b6b03b3f5)

[{'created': '2018-04-18 18:56:24.000000000', 'message': 'Fix manila driverfixes/newton checks

Branch is broken so we need 2 fixes:

1) Add upper-constraints.txt from stable/newton

   This will be used to set the upper-constraints for unit
   test jobs on this branch.

2) Backport "Remove usage of parameter enforce_type"

   oslo.config has deprecated the enforce_type parameter to
   set_override() and set its default value to True [1],
   so remove this usage from our codebase.  Also remove
   explict str() cast of mock.sentinel_password in
   Windows driver since it should no longer be expected.

   [1] Ifa552de0a994e40388cbc9f7dbaa55700ca276b0
   (cherry-picked from 4e25ce5a0c5c6100bc164729063659fd1472d391)

'}]
commit_message:
Fix manila driverfixes/newton checks

Branch is broken so we need 2 fixes:

1) Add upper-constraints.txt from stable/newton

   This will be used to set the upper-constraints for unit
   test jobs on this branch.

2) Backport "Remove usage of parameter enforce_type"

   oslo.config has deprecated the enforce_type parameter to
   set_override() and set its default value to True [1],
   so remove this usage from our codebase.  Also remove
   explict str() cast of mock.sentinel_password in
   Windows driver since it should no longer be expected.

   [1] Ifa552de0a994e40388cbc9f7dbaa55700ca276b0
   (cherry-picked from 4e25ce5a0c5c6100bc164729063659fd1472d391)

Change-Id: Id7db496441f6c1d620a4995812ed4f8c98a00ad5

subject: Handle nested providers for allocation candidates
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 1063, 'name': 'Ed Leafe', 'email': 'ed@leafe.com', 'username': 'ed-leafe'}, {'_account_id': 5754, 'name': 'Alex Xu', 'email': 'hejie.xu@intel.com', 'username': 'xuhj'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 7166, 'name': 'Sylvain Bauza', 'email': 'sbauza@redhat.com', 'username': 'sbauza'}, {'_account_id': 9708, 'name': 'Balazs Gibizer', 'display_name': 'gibi', 'email': 'gibizer@gmail.com', 'username': 'gibi'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 17920, 'name': 'Jianghua Wang', 'email': 'jianghua.wang@citrix.com', 'username': 'wjhfresh'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25625, 'name': 'Tetsuro Nakamura', 'email': 'tetsuro.nakamura.bc@hco.ntt.co.jp', 'username': 'tetsuro0907'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-27 14:58:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:06:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:07:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:08:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This isn't a previous approved spec?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:08:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This looks like a microversion bump to me in that it changes the behavior of the allocation candidates API, even if the request/response parameters don't change."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-27 15:39:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-27 17:31:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Alex & Sylvain:

The original NRP spec didn't mention the GET /a_c behavior specifically.  If it were simple, then yes, we would have continued to use the Queens NRP bp.  But we felt a new spec was needed as a vehicle to describe all of the weird semantics and corner cases we've been running into as we've been trying to develop tests & code for this functionality."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-27 17:46:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

This is a good start.  What I would like to see ideally is a section with a bullet list of all of the weird and quirky edge cases we've come across while thinking about and implementing this, what we've decided the behavior will be for each, and why.  I recognize there is some precedent for "leaving those details to code" - but in this case IMO the issues are numerous enough and complex enough that they should be spelled out in one place.

Eventually that list will feed into placement API reference content.  But the depth/scope of that text will be limited (in particular the alternatives and the whys would be absent).'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-03-28 07:01:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

At least I feel better if it is explicitly specified in the spec that we put whole tree info in provider summary even if an RP in the tree is not appeared in allocation request. That said, to be honest, I'm not catching up the reason why it is needed."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-03-28 13:52:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

Two clarification questions inline.
Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-30 13:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-03 19:01:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I've not (yet at least) go much to add here.

If we can define a path that allows us to iterate towards the final desired functionality and have some reasonable milestones along the way that would be nice."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-04-04 03:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-04-04 03:19:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-04-04 06:11:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Fine with me.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-04 14:25:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

The updates look fine.  But I'm still looking for this comment from PS2 to be addressed:

> What I would like to see ideally is a section with a bullet list of all of the weird and quirky edge cases we've come across while thinking about and implementing this, what we've decided the behavior will be for each, and why.  I recognize there is some precedent for "leaving those details to code" - but in this case IMO the issues are numerous enough and complex enough that they should be spelled out in one place.

> Eventually that list will feed into placement API reference content.  But the depth/scope of that text will be limited (in particular the alternatives and the whys would be absent).

Examples of what I meant there:

- Do you get back (empty) AllocationRequestResources entries for providers in the tree that aren't providing resource to the request?  And if so, do those providers show up in the ProviderSummaries  (We've said yes to both.)
- Do ProviderSummaries show all resources for the providers listed therein, or just the ones satisfying the request?  (We've said all, but haven't really closed on that.  Does this represent a behavior change for non-nested?  I think it does.  Can we fold that into the same microversion?  Etc.)
- Same question for traits.  (We've said we want the psums to include all the provider's traits.)
- Is it legal to get a candidate where all resources are provided by sharing providers (the "anchor" case)?  (Still some discussion needed around this.  Applies to non-nested too; but we may not be able to continue deferring it.  Can we fold into the same microversion?  Etc.)

These are just off the top of my head.  There have been others brought up.  The fact that I can't remember all the issues is a good indicator that we need a central clearing house for them.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-04-05 07:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

One point that I want to response to @efried's comments... I'm not sure folding them into the same microversion is a good idea. It at first sounds cheaper but ... is it?

Do you mean the last patch, by which "we complete to support nested candidates", follows all the changes that will have been done to support nested candidates and wind them back at once? Is that easy? Leaving each change to each contributor for each microversion sounds more reasonable and realistic to me.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-04-05 16:38:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> The updates look fine.  But I'm still looking for this comment from
 > PS2 to be addressed:
 > 
 > > What I would like to see ideally is a section with a bullet list
 > of all of the weird and quirky edge cases we've come across while
 > thinking about and implementing this, what we've decided the
 > behavior will be for each, and why.  I recognize there is some
 > precedent for "leaving those details to code" - but in this case
 > IMO the issues are numerous enough and complex enough that they
 > should be spelled out in one place.
 > 
 > > Eventually that list will feed into placement API reference
 > content.  But the depth/scope of that text will be limited (in
 > particular the alternatives and the whys would be absent).
 > 
 > Examples of what I meant there:
 > 
 > - Do you get back (empty) AllocationRequestResources entries for
 > providers in the tree that aren't providing resource to the
 > request?  And if so, do those providers show up in the
 > ProviderSummaries  (We've said yes to both.)

AFAIR, we've said that we should include all providers in selected trees in the provider_summaries, but only providers that are being consumed from in the allocation_requests section.

 > - Do ProviderSummaries show all resources for the providers listed
 > therein, or just the ones satisfying the request?  (We've said all,
 > but haven't really closed on that.  Does this represent a behavior
 > change for non-nested?  I think it does.  Can we fold that into the
 > same microversion?  Etc.)

This isn't related to nested providers, though. I think the answer to this question is "yes, we should list all the resource inventories in the provider_summaries" but this isn't related to nested resource providers.

 > - Same question for traits.  (We've said we want the psums to
 > include all the provider's traits.)

Yes, but isn't germane to nested providers.

 > - Is it legal to get a candidate where all resources are provided
 > by sharing providers (the "anchor" case)?  (Still some discussion
 > needed around this.  Applies to non-nested too; but we may not be
 > able to continue deferring it.  Can we fold into the same
 > microversion?  Etc.)

We already support allocation requests where all providers in the allocation request are sharing providers:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/tests/functional/api/openstack/placement/db/test_allocation_candidates.py#L1168

 > These are just off the top of my head.  There have been others
 > brought up.  The fact that I can't remember all the issues is a
 > good indicator that we need a central clearing house for them.

I have been satisfied with dealing with those specific scenarios as separate bug reports, frankly.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-05 18:35:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

> I have been satisfied with dealing with those specific scenarios as separate bug reports, frankly.

Difference of opinion here, I guess.  The bugs have been a great way of getting the code fixed up, but (IMO) having these design decisions and semantics collected in one place would be goodness.

> AFAIR, we've said that we should include all providers in selected trees in the provider_summaries, but only providers that are being consumed from in the allocation_requests section.

This will make it impossible to determine the target (host) for sharing-only results.  It's also going to make granular harder to implement, as it turns out.

Agree this issue and the others aren't limited to nrp; but they're mutually affected.

For the sake of expediency because we need this code ASAP, I'm going to get out of the way."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-04-05 18:41:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> > I have been satisfied with dealing with those specific scenarios
 > as separate bug reports, frankly.
 > 
 > Difference of opinion here, I guess.  The bugs have been a great
 > way of getting the code fixed up, but (IMO) having these design
 > decisions and semantics collected in one place would be goodness.
 > 
 > > AFAIR, we've said that we should include all providers in
 > selected trees in the provider_summaries, but only providers that
 > are being consumed from in the allocation_requests section.
 > 
 > This will make it impossible to determine the target (host) for
 > sharing-only results.  It's also going to make granular harder to
 > implement, as it turns out.

The allocation request is just that: the things that are **allocated against**.  It's the thing that gets sent to PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid} during claim_resources(). So, a) it doesn't make sense to list things in a request to allocate that aren't being allocated from and b) it would break the API to list non-allocated-from providers in the request to allocate something.

 > Agree this issue and the others aren't limited to nrp; but they're
 > mutually affected.
 > 
 > For the sake of expediency because we need this code ASAP, I'm
 > going to get out of the way.

I don't want you to get out of the way.

I want to make sure that a) we're solving for real-world scenarios and not theoretical ones and b) that we stick to nested providers and allocation candidates issues in this spec (since that is what was asked of me to put the spec together about).

-jay"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-06 15:52:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> The allocation request is just that: the things that are **allocated against**.  It's the thing that gets sent to PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid} during claim_resources(). So, a) it doesn't make sense to list things in a request to allocate that aren't being allocated from and b) it would break the API to list non-allocated-from providers in the request to allocate something.

Well, I'm not sure about b) - I would like to try it and see.  But if it does break, it would be easy enough to fix it to ignore empty resources dicts.

I get the philosophical angle that an empty allocation isn't an allocation.  My concern is: how does the caller figure out where an allocation should be processed for an AllocationRequest that's only got sharing providers in it?  He sorta has to go find all the aggregates for each provider, find the providers in each of those aggregates, get the root provider for each, intersect all those sets of root providers, and then pick from whatever's left.

But you're right: there's not a real use case in nova, today, where we could end up with a sharing-only AllocationRequest and not already know the target.  So we can put off solving that until it comes up.

> I don't want you to get out of the way.

I clearly did a poor job of identifying pertinent issues to use in my list of examples, probably because I had slept since the last time we had discussed one.  So until I come up with something concrete (which likely won't be until the next time I review code here), I have nothing more than a vague feeling we're glossing over details.  Which isn't a good reason for me to stand in the way of getting this spec merged.  That's all I meant."}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:01:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-04-06 17:45:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > The allocation request is just that: the things that are
 > **allocated against**.  It's the thing that gets sent to PUT
 > /allocations/{consumer_uuid} during claim_resources(). So, a) it
 > doesn't make sense to list things in a request to allocate that
 > aren't being allocated from and b) it would break the API to list
 > non-allocated-from providers in the request to allocate something.
 > 
 > Well, I'm not sure about b) - I would like to try it and see.  But
 > if it does break, it would be easy enough to fix it to ignore empty
 > resources dicts.
 > 
 > I get the philosophical angle that an empty allocation isn't an
 > allocation.  My concern is: how does the caller figure out where an
 > allocation should be processed for an AllocationRequest that's only
 > got sharing providers in it?

That was precisely the reason for my original reluctance to return allocation requests that only contain sharing providers. I was told that there was a use case for having allocation requests that only contained sharing providers, but I continue to question that use case.

For Nova, it "figures out where the allocation should be processed" by simply calling ComputeNode.get_all_by_uuids() and passing the collection of provider UUIDs that appear in the provider_summaries dict's keys. For allocation candidates where there were no compute nodes that were involved in the allocation requests, there will be zero results returned from ComputeNode.get_all_by_uuids() and therefore the scheduler will (properly) return NoValidHosts (since there are no valid hosts as targets for the instance).

 > He sorta has to go find all the
 > aggregates for each provider, find the providers in each of those
 > aggregates, get the root provider for each, intersect all those
 > sets of root providers, and then pick from whatever's left.

See above. If there's no compute node returned in the provider summaries, the scheduler is done, since there's no compute nodes to target.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-06 20:48:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I can correlate ComputeNode.get_all_by_uuids() with what's in the provider_summaries, but I can't necessarily correlate what's in the provider_summaries with an allocation request that has only sharing providers.  Because the provider_summaries represents *all* the providers for *all* of the allocation requests in the response.

A real use case for sharing-only: attaching a shared disk to an existing instance.  Here's a sample setup:

  SSP1...agg1...CN1...agg2...SSP2...agg2...CN2...agg3...SSP3
                 |
            my_instance

I ask for disk; I get allocation requests for SSP1, SSP2, and SSP3.  (I'm not sure, but I might get *two* allocation requests for SSP2.)  My provider summaries include those guys and CN1 & CN2.  Now I have to go reverse-engineer which of those allocation requests I can actually use: My instance is on CN1, so find the SSPs associated by aggregate with CN1 and intersect those with the allocation requests I got back.

(Still a sharing provider issue rather than a NRP issue.  We're gonna have a good time trying to find this discussion later :)"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-04-06 21:32:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I can correlate ComputeNode.get_all_by_uuids() with what's in the
 > provider_summaries, but I can't necessarily correlate what's in the
 > provider_summaries with an allocation request that has only sharing
 > providers.  Because the provider_summaries represents *all* the
 > providers for *all* of the allocation requests in the response.

Yes, true.

 > A real use case for sharing-only: attaching a shared disk to an
 > existing instance.  Here's a sample setup:
 > 
 > SSP1...agg1...CN1...agg2...SSP2...agg2...CN2...agg3...SSP3
 > |
 > my_instance
 > 
 > I ask for disk; I get allocation requests for SSP1, SSP2, and SSP3.
 >  (I'm not sure, but I might get *two* allocation requests for
 > SSP2.)
 >  My provider summaries include those guys and CN1 & CN2. 
 > Now I have to go reverse-engineer which of those allocation
 > requests I can actually use: My instance is on CN1, so find the
 > SSPs associated by aggregate with CN1 and intersect those with the
 > allocation requests I got back.


OK, so this use case is not a scheduling use case. Rather, this use case is describing the need to find resource providers that are associated with one or more aggregates that have available disk space.

There's no need to use allocation candidates at all.

To do that, you could easily do:

 GET /resource_providers?member_of=in:agg1,agg2&resources=DISK_GB=100&required=MISC_SHARES_VIA_AGGREGATE

That will give you the resource providers sharing DISK_GB resources with the compute node that the instance is already on (SSP1 and SSP2 assuming that the instance is on CN1). The thing that is issuing the query above would then need to read the existing instance's allocations, create a new allocation set with some DISK_GB resources supplied from either SSP1 or SSP2 and re-PUT /allocations/{instance_uuid} with that updated set of allocations.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-06 21:40:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

That seems to be circumventing much of the benefit of /allocation_candidates.  And you still had to go figure out which aggregates your compute node is in.  But it works for this simple example, which is probably all we need for the forseeable future.

Another option in the general case for the future would be to add a qparam to /allocation_candidates that lets you limit results to one (or more) provider(s).  It would be corollary to /resource_providers?uuid= or ?name= - though we would have to name it provider_uuid= / provider_name= (and perhaps support `in:`).

Later.  Later.'}, {'account_id': 17920, 'date': '2018-04-10 02:21:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-04-10 09:01:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-12 15:14:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-04-16 06:11:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-16 10:57:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-16 22:29:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-04-18 14:36:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

Nothing really important to fix. Thanks for that, just provide a follow-up fixing change for the nits if needed.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-04-18 14:38:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

FWIW, I also understand why we need a spec (just because of the microversion) but honestly, let's don't rat-hole about any implementation question here."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-18 18:48:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-18 19:54:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-04-19 07:55:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

All the scheduling team guys on board. I also have no more question.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-19 12:01:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Since this is already merged, I would appreciate a follow up to amend this spec to clarify its position with respect to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559466/.'}]

commit_message:
Handle nested providers for allocation candidates

Add support for handling provider trees when evaluating providers that
meet requested resource and trait constraints.

Change-Id: If4fcf5a0bdddc6484ebdfc1385a46a85243b909f
blueprint: nested-resource-providers-allocation-candidates

[{'created': '2018-04-18 15:32:16.000000000', 'message': "Remove perl library from Ubuntu installs

It seems that the package was added a long time ago [1], and might
have been needed for the percona tooling. This makes sense if we're
downloading the dep - but we're no longer doing that and can rely
on apt's resolver to find the correct packages.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/238748

Change-Id: I742c4ef9a201384787d5a9aeafac4ff7b0bdc353
(cherry picked from commit 6f1d10063aac57f66dd7549028e090aed00dca7a)

commit_message:
Remove perl library from Ubuntu installs

It seems that the package was added a long time ago [1], and might
have been needed for the percona tooling. This makes sense if we're
downloading the dep - but we're no longer doing that and can rely
on apt's resolver to find the correct packages.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/238748

Change-Id: I742c4ef9a201384787d5a9aeafac4ff7b0bdc353
(cherry picked from commit 6f1d10063aac57f66dd7549028e090aed00dca7a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-30 18:23:01.000000000', 'message': 'Support simple FIP disassociation (with FIP release)

We previously supported so-called "Simple FIP disassociation"
which allows users to disassociate and release a FIP in a single action.
We no longer support nova-network based features, but I believe it is worth
implemented even in a neutron-only era. This patch introduces a checkbox
"Release floating IP" to support this with neutron.

At the same time, this patch also fixes a bug that the existing FIP
disassociation action disassociates and releases a first FIP of
a requested server. Even though it is a rare case where a single
server has multiple FIPs, this is a bug. After this patch, FIPs
associated with the requested server are listed in the form and
a user can select an FIP to be disassociated.

This patch drops a setting parameter 'simple_ip_management' without
deprecation notice. This is actually no side effect because this setting
just toggled the FIP disassociate action in the instance table and
it provides nothing more than that. We can do the same thing by
the policy file.

TODOs:
- Write a release note on the new feature 'Release Floating IP' checkbox
- Write a release note on the drop of simple_ip_management setting
- Write unit tests to cover this

Change-Id: Ie8053bdd3a3e4c7897c7c906788d40c2a1d3f708
Closes-Bug: #1226003

commit_message:
Support simple FIP disassociation (with FIP release)

We previously supported so-called "Simple FIP disassociation"
which allows users to disassociate and release a FIP in a single action.
We no longer support nova-network based features, but I believe it is worth
implemented even in a neutron-only era. This patch introduces a checkbox
"Release floating IP" to support this with neutron.

At the same time, this patch also fixes a bug that the existing FIP
disassociation action disassociates and releases a first FIP of
a requested server. Even though it is a rare case where a single
server has multiple FIPs, this is a bug. After this patch, FIPs
associated with the requested server are listed in the form and
a user can select an FIP to be disassociated.

This patch drops a setting parameter 'simple_ip_management' without
deprecation notice. This is actually no side effect because this setting
just toggled the FIP disassociate action in the instance table and
it provides nothing more than that. We can do the same thing by
the policy file.

Change-Id: Ie8053bdd3a3e4c7897c7c906788d40c2a1d3f708
Closes-Bug: #1226003

commit_message:
Only display the bootable volume snapshots when creating instance

The volume snapshot of non-bootable volume could not be as the instance source.
But now,when we select volume snapshot as source, not only bootable volume
snapshots but also non-bootable ones show up.

Change-Id: I36cd02f34029eedb693047a1bf3f01dad05aa1b3
Closes-Bug: #1748724

commit_message:
Add IP addresses to infra node br-vxlan in the examples

The layer 3 agent is no longer containerised by default so the bare
metal host requires an IP to be assigned to br-vxlan

Closes-Bug: #1761715
(cherry picked from commit 55e8240b86e5b14c9b2bd78e29a207a0c2bb0d6f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-13 15:07:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix multinode mode for devstack

Extend the devstack job so that it can support both single and multinode
cases.  Multinode mode require extra settings in devstack configuration,
some of which as subnode specific, some controller specific.

Also keep a simple devstack-multinode job defined for now so we can run
a multinode job in devstack gate, until the full tempest multinode job
is ready to match the old
gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-multinode-full-ubuntu-xenial-nv.

Fixing multinode also requires sharing the CA configuration between
controller and peers, overlay network configuration for communication
between virtual machines and running discover_hosts for nova after the
subnode has been setup.

The extra orchestration required for multinode is encoded in a
dedicated role to allow for jobs in other repos to re-use it.

This backport is slightly modified from the original, since master does
not use the test-matrix anymore, while on stable branches we still rely
on it.

Change-Id: I2dcbd9bdb401860820e655d97aa3c4775af2827f
'}]
commit_message:
Fix multinode mode for devstack

Extend the devstack job so that it can support both single and multinode
cases.  Multinode mode require extra settings in devstack configuration,
some of which as subnode specific, some controller specific.

Also keep a simple devstack-multinode job defined for now so we can run
a multinode job in devstack gate, until the full tempest multinode job
is ready to match the old
gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-multinode-full-ubuntu-xenial-nv.

Fixing multinode also requires sharing the CA configuration between
controller and peers, overlay network configuration for communication
between virtual machines and running discover_hosts for nova after the
subnode has been setup.

The extra orchestration required for multinode is encoded in a
dedicated role to allow for jobs in other repos to re-use it.

This backport is slightly modified from the original, since master does
not use the test-matrix anymore, while on stable branches we still rely
on it.

Change-Id: I2dcbd9bdb401860820e655d97aa3c4775af2827f

[{'created': '2018-04-17 21:18:46.000000000', 'message': "Fix handling of dstport option for VXLANs

When specifying a value for the 'dstport' option in the [vxlan] section
of the Linux bridge agent, the agent crashes upon start. This is
because the value specified in 'dstport' is incorrectly converted to
a string before being passed to pyroute2 when creating a VXLAN tunnel.
pyroute2 expects an integer value. This patch fixes this bug.

Change-Id: I83131f3bb32253cbc4acec3a1f38bf225223ff8b
Closes-Bug: #1764867
"}]
commit_message:
Fix handling of dstport option for VXLANs

When specifying a value for the 'dstport' option in the [vxlan] section
of the Linux bridge agent, the agent crashes upon start. This is
because the value specified in 'dstport' is incorrectly converted to
a string before being passed to pyroute2 when creating a VXLAN tunnel.
pyroute2 expects an integer value. This patch fixes this bug.

Change-Id: I83131f3bb32253cbc4acec3a1f38bf225223ff8b
Closes-Bug: #1764867

commit_message:
Provide an example of how to Customize OpenStack Ceph Pools

The current documentation doesn't explain how to customize
the placement group number for each ceph pool individually.
Adds a new section with an example.

commit_message:
use rpc Connection rather than create_connection

The create_connection function in neutron.common.rpc is just an alias to
Connection. This patch switches to the later so we can remove the former
in: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/560130

[{'created': '2018-04-15 22:41:39.000000000', 'message': "Create BuildRequires repo for master

Since Rocky, RDO is spliting dependencies repo in two different
repos, one for runtime requirement with the URL used in previous
releases and a new one with the packages that are only required
to build packages. This repo is not needed to deploy RDO but it's
needed to build packages with DLRN as done in Tripleo-CI jobs.

This patch is adding this new repository for master as it's needed
in the build-test-packages role in oooqe.

Additionally, this patch is changing URL for runtime to use
master repo.

Change-Id: I74388434e3dccfea2754569a6bc568835d49b5e2
"}]
commit_message:
Create BuildRequires repo for master

Since Rocky, RDO is spliting dependencies repo in two different
repos, one for runtime requirement with the URL used in previous
releases and a new one with the packages that are only required
to build packages. This repo is not needed to deploy RDO but it's
needed to build packages with DLRN as done in Tripleo-CI jobs.

This patch is adding this new repository for master as it's needed
in the build-test-packages role in oooqe.

Additionally, this patch is changing URL for runtime to use
master repo.

Change-Id: I74388434e3dccfea2754569a6bc568835d49b5e2

commit_message:
Add no_group parameter to hashmap "list_*" calls

The "no_group" parameter is available in the API and in the hashmap module's
"list_mappings" and "list_thresholds" functions, but it is ignored.

This patch fixes it by passing the parameter through.

Change-Id: I5ab4e664c90144bb722eb5ce47129a6cece5fd53

commit_message:
Enable Swift encryption for the containerized undercloud

This adds a new parameter to undercloud.conf for the containerized case.
It determines whether or not we should enable Swift Object encryption.
If we do enable it, it will add the Barbican service and configure
encryption for Swift.

Depends-On: I9c5e07a2eb764168670d5de7bdeb4b6362f9bfb5
Change-Id: I7826cc00023e2d24865d752d4c9bbb3cc4c8614f

commit_message:
Include Barbican's KEK in undercloud passwords

We take the autogenerated Key Encryption Key for barbican into use in
the undercloud passwords file, so this can work with swift encryption.

Change-Id: I6f2c5b098523749e1cb0828367bf5c7c8dba0f41

commit_message:
libvirt: Drop MIN_LIBVIRT_KVM_PPC64_VERSION

The updated minimum required libvirt (3.8.0) and QEMU (2.8.0) for
"Rocky" matches this now, so we can drop the compatibility code.

Also remove / fix relevant unit tests.

Change-Id: I025aa99382a43f142b37f7e600b163cfcf95a2db
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: Drop MIN_LIBVIRT_VIRTUOZZO_VERSION

The updated minimum required libvirt (3.8.0) and QEMU (2.8.0) for
"Rocky" matches this now, so we can drop the compatibility code.

Also fix relevant unit tests.

Change-Id: I839188d2f41209c551812199d5704305d0f12837
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: Drop MIN_{LIBVIRT_KVM,QEMU}_S390_VERSION

The updated minimum required libvirt (3.8.0) and QEMU (2.8.0) for
"Rocky" matches this now, so we can drop the compatibility code.

Also remove / fix relevant unit tests.

Change-Id: I8f931fd4268f0b7fac939568ebc0a577989c410e
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Only set verbosity if level above 1

Cliff sets the verbosity level to 0 for the quiet option. The normal
verbosity option is 1. So, to reflect this, I set the same in the
client.

Change-Id: I105fb6b37769411178cff5f2c8ea0496f2a9cd2e

Change-Id: I9c5e07a2eb764168670d5de7bdeb4b6362f9bfb5

commit_message:
Add Barbican to the list of services for the undercloud

It's disabled by default, and will be an option to use if we decide to
enable Swift volume encryption for the undercloud.

Change-Id: I9c5e07a2eb764168670d5de7bdeb4b6362f9bfb5

commit_message:
Fix typo in inventory's output file.

Fix suffix in file's name to prevent error:
awk: fatal: cannot open file `/tmp/fake-oc-hosts.yaml'
 for reading (No such file or directory)

(Fix only for: stable/queens)

Closes-Bug: 1765313
Change-Id: If8965ac4b579a91d71bded7ee769c5438c421476

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-17 13:45:40.000000000', 'message': 'ovn: Mount /run instead of /run/openvswitch when starting ovn-controller container

Presently ovn-controller container is started with "-v /run/openvswitch:/run/openvswitch".
The openvswitch systemd script deletes the /run/openvswitch folder when stopping it in the host.
/run/openvswitch path inside the ovn-controller container becomes a stale directory.
And when the service is started again, it creates the folder again. In order for ovn-controller
to access again, the folder has to be remounted or the ovn-controller container should be
restarted.

To fix this, this patch mounts /run so that when /run/openvswitch is created again, it will
get reflected inside the ovn-controller container.

Closes-bug: #1764745
Change-Id: I032571cec49537cac972ebbbb44733ea17c299fa
'}, {'created': '2018-04-18 06:57:01.000000000', 'message': 'ovn: Mount /run instead of /run/openvswitch when starting ovn-controller container

Presently ovn-controller container is started with "-v /run/openvswitch:/run/openvswitch".
The openvswitch systemd script deletes the /run/openvswitch folder when stopping it in the host.
/run/openvswitch path inside the ovn-controller container becomes a stale directory.
And when the service is started again, it creates the folder again. In order for ovn-controller
to access again, the folder has to be remounted or the ovn-controller container should be
restarted.

As a temporary fix, this patch mounts /run so that when /run/openvswitch is created again, it will
get reflected inside the ovn-controller container. The proper fix has to come from openvswitch
systemd script to not delete /run/openvswitch when stopping the service. This is presently
discusses in OVS mailing list [1], but no proper solution has been arrived yet.

[1] - https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-dev/2018-March/345589.html
Closes-bug: #1764745
Change-Id: I032571cec49537cac972ebbbb44733ea17c299fa
'}]
commit_message:
ovn: Mount /run instead of /run/openvswitch when starting ovn-controller container

Presently ovn-controller container is started with "-v /run/openvswitch:/run/openvswitch".
The openvswitch systemd script deletes the /run/openvswitch folder when stopping it in the host.
/run/openvswitch path inside the ovn-controller container becomes a stale directory.
And when the service is started again, it creates the folder again. In order for ovn-controller
to access again, the folder has to be remounted or the ovn-controller container should be
restarted.

As a temporary fix, this patch mounts /run so that when /run/openvswitch is created again, it will
get reflected inside the ovn-controller container. The proper fix has to come from openvswitch
systemd script to not delete /run/openvswitch when stopping the service. This is presently
discusses in OVS mailing list [1], but no proper solution has been arrived yet.

[1] - https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-dev/2018-March/345589.html
Closes-bug: #1764745
Change-Id: I032571cec49537cac972ebbbb44733ea17c299fa

commit_message:
Update monasca-transform devstack plugin

* set "publish_region" config value from
  variable "$REGION_NAME"
* set default "publish_kafka_project_id"
  to "mini-mon" instead of "admin"
* update the systemd service unit file
  since that file is created by devstack's
  "run_process" function
  - set KillMode to 'control-group', since
    monasca-tranform generates several
    child process
* remove monasca-transform.service file
  since its now being generated by devstack
  plugin.

Change-Id: I6654b7973f8502d4805d25c96b2038291e398552
Story: 2001815
Task: 14328

commit_message:
Add pagination support to API

This allows pagination on all API endpoints returning a list (*Collection
datamodels). Pagination can be done through the 'limit' and 'offset'
parameters. A limit set to 0 means no limit

CloudKitty types are sometimes imported as 'cktypes' and sometimes
as 'ck_types'. In order to stay consistent, they have all been renamed
to 'ck_types'.

Change-Id: Id642f09dac7722737bd6098341d418da1c9be549
Story: 2001275
Task: 5809

commit_message:
Add tenant id to quote API

The rate rule always related to tenant id, so the quote api should
use tenant id too.

Change-Id: I5c98d49c41f4b54f88092dd0d0ee05ad4593cd53

From 10 minutes to 1 hour.

Closes-Bug: #1757487

Update DellEMC Manila Unity driver

commit_message:
Fix a plural mistake REVIEWING.rst

Reviewing the REVIEWING.rst of tempest,
I noticed a plural mistake.
The word "APIs" is plural and it shouldn't add 'a' in the front.
And there is an extra "that" before "which".
So I fix it.

Change-Id: I84d81f44314feadaebfcd4a834f854364328593b

[{'created': '2018-03-23 04:03:49.000000000', 'message': 'add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ie5da1d132321b2cffea3eb8522462daad45900b5
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Also fix the lower bound for requests-kerberos.

Change-Id: Ie5da1d132321b2cffea3eb8522462daad45900b5
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Optimize reconfiguration for octavia
